item.title: How using unstable software was a great decision
item.description: I use Laravel. It is an extremely popular PHP framework, and it has the definite right to be. Laravel is simply a pleasure to work with. About 4 months ago I started planning a new project. I had to make the important decision of whether or not to use the unstable, not-even-beta Laravel 5, or the tried and true Laravel 4. I ended up choosing 5 for a couple of reasons.

item.title: I bought a microcomputer. Here's what I do with it
item.description: If you’re reading this blog, you’re surely familiar with the RaspberryPi, a ~$30 microcomputer. Only, I didn’t buy the RaspberryPi, I bought the ODROID-C1 by HardKernel for $35. The C1 has 4 cores, generously provided by the Amlogic S805 SoC with ARMv7 architecture, and 1GB of DDR3 RAM. As opposed to the RaspberryPi B+, which is also $35, having only 1 core on ARMv6 architecture and 512MB of DDR2 RAM.

item.title: You should adhere to ISO 8601
item.description: If you aren’t already sold on this date format, let me elaborate. The International Organization for Standardization, or ISO, is a committee that sets forth standards intended for 163 countries. You undoubtedly use something everyday that adheres to some specification provided by the organization. For example: film speed is defined by ISO 6, 2240, and 5800. And the file extension .ISO (used for disk images) pays homage to ISO 9660. Country (“us”, “uk”) and language codes (“en”, “es”) stem from ISO 3166 and 639 respectively.
